title: Software
text:
FSA (Fisheries Stock Assessment): R functions to conduct typical introductory fisheries analyses. Example analyses that use FSA are in the Introductory Fisheries Analyses with R book.
FSAdata: A companion to FSA with data sets for use in common fisheries analyses.
RFishBC: Helps collect measurements from calcified structures and back-calculate estimated lengths at previous ages.







These packages are now maintained by the fishR-Core-Team, of which I am a member.

Unreleased R Packages

FSAWs: For constructing and validating standard weight (Ws) equations for fish.
NCStats: Helper functions for statistics courses at Northland College.







Other packages that are less well-developed or maintained are available on my Github page

title: Software
text:
Contributions to Other R Packages

plotrix::histStack(): Construct histograms with bars stacked according to a categorical variable.
pgirmess::kruskalmc(): A generic wrapper function for performing multiple comparisons for a Kruskal-Wallis test.
car::leveneTest(): A generic wrapper function for performing Levene’s homogeneity of variances test.
plotrix::plotH(): Construct histogram-like modifications of scatterplots.

title: Derek H. Ogle
text:
I worked for Northland College as a fisheries and statistics professor for 26 years until 2022. I believe in Northland’s mission and core values surrounding the environment, sustainability, and social justice. I very much enjoyed helping students to reach their academic and career goals.
While at Northland (and both before and since) I had opportunities to pursue my own scholarly interests. Towards that end I authored a fisheries-related book, book chapter, and several journal articles, and developed software mostly related to fisheries analyses.
Though retired from that career I still, as part of the fishR core team, actively maintain the fishR webpage1 and several fisheries-related R packages.
My professional record is recorded on my CV and in the links above and below.

title: Derek H. Ogle

title: Propane Prices
text:
Recently I have been considering the relative costs of propane and wood for heating our house. One of the considerations for propane is how the cost fluctuates from year-to-year and within a year. Most propane companies offer a “lock-in” price to protect against the supposedly inevitable increase in the cost of propane during the winter. I questioned whether this was a good investment or not (like many things, I suspected it was better for the propane company than me).
The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) has a website that shows the price per gallon of propane in Mont Belvieu, TX, as well as the wholesale and residential prices of propane during the heating season for a variety of regions and states. Both pages provide an option to download the data, which I did to play with below.
Figure 1: My propane tank.

title: Propane Prices
text:
Complete Time Series
Mont Belvieu is a large propane (and other gas) storage location in Texas and the primary pricing point for propane (see this1). Thus, examining the price of propane at Mont Belvieu may indicate the basis for current and future propane prices locally.
1 And this for a brief but interesting note about propane storage in Mont Belvieu.Figure 2 shows the daily price per gallon of propane at Mont Belvieu. There was a clear increase in price throughout the 2000s. Since then prices have varied, somewhat dramatically at times. Prices have dropped in the last year or so.








Figure 2: Daily propane spot price (per gallon) at Mont Belvieu, TX.





Boxplots of average annual heating year prices (i.e., July to June) show the same basic trends – increase in the 2000s and more variability since then (Figure 3).








Figure 3: Annual heating year (July to June) boxplots of daily propane spot price (per gallon) at Mont Belvieu, TX.

title: Propane Prices
text:
Inter-Annual Seasonal Trends
My common thought (shared by many others, especially those selling propane to customers) is that propane prices would be higher in fall and winter than spring and summer. Figure 4 shows the daily prices (per gallon) separately for each of the last 14 heating years (July to June) to more easily see inter-annual trends. My thought was supported in years like 2016-17 and 2020-21, but was not supported in many other years. Furthermore, I don’t see a consistent inter-annual trend among years.








Figure 4: Daily propane spot price (per gallon) at Mont Belvieu, TX separated by annual heating year (July to June). The horizontal gray lines are the heating year average and the light gray box is the approximate heating season (15-Nov to 15-Apr). Note that each plot has a different y-axis scale.

title: Water Heights at Flynn Lake Dam
text: The winter of 2022-23 was exceptionally snowy in northern Wisconsin (see this). Landowners around the Pike Lake Chain expressed concerns about high water levels on the lakes soon after ice-out that year as “beaches” and docks were under water. A relative depth gauge is affixed to a permanent “wall” a few feet upstream from the dam on Flynn Lake (i.e., the outlet of the Pike Lake Chain). With the help of some friends (see Acknowledgments below), I now have near daily water level measurements at the gauge from May 2, 2023 to January 6, 2026. I hope these data will help us better understand both typical and atypical water levels on the lakes. My analysis and interpretation of these data are below. More information about the data collection is further below.

title: Water Heights at Flynn Lake Dam
text:
Water Level
It is difficult to make definitive conclusions from only two complete ice-out to ice-out seasons. However, a few preliminary thoughts are:

Median water levels over the season appear to be around 22.5-23.0” (Figure 2; Table 1).
There is considerable year-to-year variability (Figure 1; Figure 2), even during the middle of “summer” or “winter” when I expected the levels to be fairly consistent across years.
Water levels are dependent on rainfall (not surprisingly!). The levels at the start of the 2023-24 season were elevated due to near record snowfalls the previous winter, whereas the lowest recordings (thusfar) were at the end of the summer for the 2024-25 season when we experience near drought-like conditions (Figure 1).
The water level at the beginning of 2023-24 (i.e., end of 2022-23 winter) may have been atypically high as it was at least 5” higher than the water level at ice-out in 2024-25, 4” higher than the water level at ice-out in 2025-26, and 3” higher than any other water level recorded in 2023-24 after the initial peak had subsided (Figure 1; Table 1). Furthermore, the water level dropped rather quickly in spring of 2023 suggesting that there was excess water in the system that simply needed time to be flushed out (Figure 1).









Figure 1: Daily water level at Flynn Lake dam by “ice-out to ice-out season.”













Figure 2: Distribution of daily water level at Flynn Lake dam by “ice-out to ice-out season.” Ends of white box are the 25th and 75th percentiles and the horizontal line is the median (50th percentile). The distribution for the current season will look odd when few data exist early in the season.

title: Water Heights at Flynn Lake Dam
text:
Change in Water Level
As seen in Figure 1 and Table 1, there can be considerable day-to-day variability in water level at the Flynn dam. Of course, the large increases are due to precipitation and the extended periods of decline in water level are due to lack of precipitation. Here are some preliminary thoughts about the daily changes in water level.

The greatest daily change in water level was an increase of 2.4 on July 14, 2025 following 2.86” of rain. Interestingly lower daily water level increases were observed following greater amounts of rain on other dates (Figure 3).
It appears that, without any additional precipitation, lake water levels generally drop about 1/8” to 1/4” per day (Figure 4; Figure 5) until a baseline level between 21” and 22” is approached (Figure 1; Figure 3). Near that baseline the drop in lake water level tends to be less.
Lake water levels can increase substantially with precipitation (Figure 5) but the actual rise does not always match the amount of precipitation, sometimes being more and sometimes being less than the precipitation amount (Figure 3; Figure 4).









Figure 3: Change in water level from the previous day at Flynn Lake dam by “ice-out to ice-out season.” Points represent precipitation events since the previous observation color coded by the amount of precipitation.













Figure 4: Distribution of the change from the previous day in daily water level at Flynn Lake dam by “ice-out to ice-out season.” Ends of white box are the 25th and 75th percentiles and the horizontal line is the median (50th percentile). The distribution for the current season will look odd when few data exist early in the season.













Figure 5: Distribution of the change from the previous day in daily water level at Flynn Lake dam by categories of rain prior to the measurement. Dots represent observations, though there is considerable over-plotting at the lower rain amounts.

title: Water Heights at Flynn Lake Dam
text:
Data Collection
Data collection is pretty straightforward for this project. I, or a friend, record the water level at the gauge to the nearest 0.01’ each day (as possible) as close to noon as possible. On the few days where we could not make the reading, I linearly interpolated the water level from the two adjacent readings. Surprisingly, it is harder to read the gauge then you would imagine. On a few days, we had multiple people read the gauge and from this I expect the “human error” of the readings to be about 0.01’.
The lake water level readings should be considered as “relative” values as it is not clear to me what the gauge is measuring from. In other words, a reading of 21” is not meaningful in and of itself (i.e. 21” from what?), but it does have meaning relative to another measurement of, say, 24” (i.e., it is 3” lower).
Precipitation measurements are from my data recorded for the CoCoRaHS Network at a location near the shore of Eagle Lake, the next lake upstream from Flynn Lake. Snow was converted to a “snow water equivalent” (SWE) to most closely compare with rain. Ice out was for Eagle Lake as recorded by Gary Hagstrom (see this).

title: Water Heights at Flynn Lake Dam
text:
Acknowledgments
Thanks to Hal A, Ieuan A, Joe R., Kevin S., Sjana S, and Tim T. for taking the measurements when I could not!!

title: Eagle Lake Ice-Out
text:
Ice-Out Dates








Figure 1: Eagle Lake ice out dates (gray line and points) by year (note no data for 2008). Solid red line is a loess trend line.





 








Figure 2: Eagle Lake ice out dates, 1999-2024.

title: Eagle Lake Ice-Out
text:
Comparison to Other Lakes
Lake Nebagamon is much larger (986 acres) but with a similar maximum depth (56 ft) as Eagle Lake that is approximately 20 miles nearly straight west of Eagle Lake. With the exception of a few notable years, the ice-out dates between these two lakes are quite similar. Lake Mendota is a very large (9781 acres) and deep (83 ft maximum) lake that is approximately 350 miles south of Eagle Lake. The ice-out dates for Mendota are always before those for Eagle Lake, but they very generally track together.








Figure 3: Eagle Lake ice out dates by year with other lakes shown for comparison.

title: Eagle Lake Ice-Out
text:
Data Notes
These data were recorded by Gary Hagstrom. His general criterion was “complete ice out”; i.e., the lake completely devoid of ice with the exception of small remnants on north-facing shores.
Dates show above have been adjusted for leap years to maintain consistency across years. For example, Gary recorded ice out in 2024, a leap year, as 14-Mar but it appears as 15-Mar above to account for the extra “leap day” in Feb. In other words, 14-Mar is later in the year in a leap year then it is in a non leap year, which is accounted for above. Leap years are shown with triangles (rather than circles) in the time series graphs above.

title: Cash
text:
Cash
We have had Cash since September 2020. He is a spirited “big pony” who loves to be outside, especially on walks/hikes. The latest picture of Cash is below; go here to see a picture from (nearly) each week of his life.



Week 282


 


Jem
Jem graced our lives from April(ish) 2009 to almost August 2018. Many people knew Jem from seeing him around the Science Center during the school year. Jem was such a special dog … very smart, incredibly loyal, and always watching over and protecting us. While he was a little snooty and often turned up his nose at “strangers”, he also melted your heart if he decided to give you the time of day. Here is a short piece that I wrote about Jem a few years ago.
Jem was taken from us way too early, though we know he is now with his “grandpa owner” taking walks, sitting on the couch together, and scheming to get those chippies. RIP “poundy”, I wish we would have had more time together, you were such a special little guy!! We will see you again (Thanks Ronnie … beautiful song).














































































 


Jordan
Kim and I got Jordan soon in 1991, soon after we were married. “Jordo” enriched our lives until March 2006. We miss the walks and boat rides. RIP “Bordo Dog”!!!

title: Potawatomi State Park
text: On the way home from Door County on April 17, 2023, Kim, Cash and I stopped at Potawatomi State Park to get in one more hike, even though the weather had changed dramatically (it was now snowing!). We parked between the two campgrounds and followed the Tower Trail out to the tower and the Old Ski Hill Overlook. We returned inland mostly on the Tower Trail though we got off on a couple of ski trails and the Ancients Shorelines Trail. This was a nice hike, though the first portion along the lake was our favorite.

title: Weaver’s Needle Cross Loop
text: I hiked a loop that included Weaver’s Needle Crosscut trail on February 11, 2024. The loop begins with the Dutchman’s Trail and Brush Spring Trail that forms the end of the Cave Trail loop. I continued on the Brush Spring Trail through a pass into Needle Canyon. I then hopped on the Terrapin Trail to Bluff Saddle where I began the Weaver’s Needle Crosscut Trail. The first half or so of the crosscut trail is easy to follow but the last half requires some scrambling before a fairly quick descent to the Peralta Canyon Trail. I don’t think I followed a typical path but I could see the Peralta Canyon Trail and just navigated my way down it. I then returned on the Peralta Canyon Trail through Fremont’s Saddle and down to the Peralta Trailhead. This was a beautiful day hike that I will definitely do again.

title: Flatiron via Siphon Draw
text: On February 9, 2025 I hiked up Siphon Draw to the Flatiron. I had done this trail five or so years ago, but not since then (and not with my phone for mapping). This was a beautiful weekend day so the draw was full of hikers (but not too many). The trail was easier to follow, but steeper, than I remembered. The view from The Flatiron were still amazing. The climb down is not that much fun, but still worth it.

title: Robber’s Roost Loop
text: On February 25, 2023 I hiked to Robber’s Roost via the Carney Springs Trail (starting at the Lost Goldmine East TH) and returning via the Cave Trail. The climb up the Carney Springs Canyon got my heart pumping (~1300 feet elevation gain in a little over a mile). Finding the path into Robber’s Roost was difficult, but as I got closer I could hear voices and when I met the hikers outside of the Roost they offered to show me the “secret” passage into it (Thanks, Juan). It was amazing to stand in the Roost and the views out the fractures in the wall were beautiful. I returned through Fremont Saddle (a little less than a mile from the Roost) and down the Cave Trail, which had some navigational challenges as it did last year (I did not miss Geronimo’s Cave this year, though!). This was a challenging (the climb and some route-finding), but beautiful (views from on top, the Roost) hike that I will do again (with Kim).

title: Praying Hands Loop
text: On February 8, 2025 Kim and I hiked past the Praying Hands Rock via several trails, including the Praying Hands trail, off the First Water Road. The route was fairly flat along Jacob’s Crosscut Trail but began to climb while on Prospector’s View, Treasure Loop, and the start of Praying Hands trails. At the saddle near Praying Hands Rock we detoured to take a “social trail” behind a cut rock, which eventually required quite a bit of scrambling in loose rock (on some fairly steep areas) before reconnecting with the Praying Hands Trail. That sidetrack was fun, but probably not needed! The Praying Hands Trail back to the parking lot was a fairly easy gradual descent. Fun trail. Would do it again.

The Peralta Trail Canyon (102) portion is a moderately steep climb to Fremont Saddle for a great view of Weaver’s Needle. We took a short walk out to a Pinon tree for a closer view of the Needle. The Cave Trail portion was a challenge to find and included some scrambling. A fun trail all around. Details are below.

title: Lost Goldmine Trail
text: On February 10, 2024 Kim and I “eased” into hiking in the desert again by walking the Lost Goldmine Trail from the Hieroglyphics Trailhead to the Carney Springs Trail (nearly to where it goes to the Wave Cave). This trail is relatively flat but provides some great views of cacti as well as the sides and peaks of Turk’s Head and Superstition Ridge. The day was rainy so there were not many others on the trail. We did, however, “meet” some cattle grazing in parts of the trail that were not in the Superstition Wilderness. This was a fun hike.

title: Hackberry Springs Loop
text: On February 24, 2023 Kim and I hiked the Hackberry Springs loop (from the First Water TH) on a beautiful sunny day. This loop was one of the first hikes we did five or so years ago. At that time we had very little experience and were navigating with a small map in a dated book. We completed the hike then but it was much more comfortable this time as we had more experience hiking in the desert and were using our Avenza. This is quite a beautiful trail, especially on the way down to and out of Hackberry Springs. My favorite part is the high bluffs along the stream.

title: Superstition Wilderness Hiking
text:
Kim’s Mom has a place near Superstition Mountain which we try to visit annually. In 2022 I started mapping hikes that we made in the Superstition Wilderness. Those hikes are shown below. More information on some specific walks is in the next section.

title: Other Notable Hikes
text:
I commonly hike near home, other places in Wisconsin and Minnesota, near my childhood home, and in the Superstition Mountains (AZ), but we also like to hike in other areas while on vacations. These “one-off” hikes are listed below (in reverse chronological order).


Kim and I went to Virginia Beach on February 27-29, 2025 to watch her niece Journey compete in the Atlantic 10 Indoor Track Championships. The highlights of the trip were that Journey earned gold (triple jump) and silver (long jump) medals and we got to spend some fun time with her. Part of that time was a hike in First Landing State Park before the championships began. Just for fun, we also mapped the boardwalk.

title: Wasson Peak Loop
text: On February 13, 2025 Kim and I hiked to Wasson Peak in Saguaro National Park [West]. We hiked clockwise starting on the Gould Mine Trail, continuing on the Sendero Esperanza Trail, before taking the Hugh Norris Trail all the way to the peak. On the way back we followed the King Canyon trail into the King Canyon wash back to the parking lot. The trail was very easy to follow with a nice tread. There was some elevation change but the views, especially from Wasson Peak, were beautiful. The petroglyphs in the wash were a nice treat on the way back.

title: Trummelbach Falls Loop
text: On our First day in Lauterbrunnen (October 10, 2024) we left our hotel to walk through the city and countryside to the Trummelbach waterfalls. Lauterbrunnen is stunningly beautiful sitting in deep valley with steep walls. Thus, the hike to Trummelback was jaw-dropping gorgeous in every direction. We stopped along the way to view Staubbach Falls up close, as there is a side trail passing through a tunnel that gets you in the spray of this highest (297 m) free-falling waterfall in Switzerland! From there it is a leisurely walk on roads (not busy) or trails to the entrance to Trummelbach Falls. The Trummelbach waterfalls are Europe’s largest subterranean water falls. The falls can be viewed from a number of different vantage points that are connected with underground paths, platforms, and a lift. Access to the falls was well worth the $15CHF entry fee. Following the falls we returned to the main town and our hotel using a slight different route that was less busy and mostly followed the river. This was a great hike and experience!!

title: Hunter Trail, Picacho Peak State Park, AZ
text: On February 11, 2025 Kim and I hiked the Hunter Trail to Picacho Peak in Picacho Peak State Park. The trail is fairly steep, but with many switchbacks, up to a “saddle” with a beautiful view. The trail then descends very steeply before climbing up the “back side” of the mountain to Picacho Peak. Several spots on this part of the trail were very steep, on smooth rock, or on the “edge” such that you needed to use the (very handy) cables for climbing. This was quite an adventure but well worth it for the 360o views at the peak.

title: City Bridges Walk
text: Soon after getting to Lucerne on October 11, 2024, we headed out to explore the city along the river near our hotel. We walked along the Reuss River, crossing the river first (and ultimately twice) at the beautiful wooden Spreurbrucke, then at the modern Geissmattbrucke, and finally at the iconic Kapelbrucke (aka Chapel Bridge). The Kapelbrucke is thought to be the oldest wooden bridge in Switzerland and is magnificent with its old wood, paintings, and flowers. I included a few pictures of Kapelbrucke at night, where it is even more beautiful.

title: Riffelberg to Gornergrat
text: On October 9, 2024, Kim and I took the Gornergrat Bahn to the Riffelberg station (8471’), hiked from there to the Gornergrat station (10132’), and took the train back to Zermatt. The hike from Riffelberg to Riffelsee was beautiful with constant and amazing views of the Matterhorn and other “lesser” mountains. There were few people on this portion of the trail, though the area around Riffelsee was busy with people walking down from the Rotenboden station. From Riffelsee we decided to take a side trail rather then walk with all of the people on the trail from Rotenboden up to Gornergrat. This was a great decision as we did not see any people after Rotenboden until we got to Gornergrat and the scenery was breathtaking. Most of this trail was fairly flat along a steep mountainside above a valley carved out by a still existing glacier. The views of the glacier were especially spectacular as we started high enough to get the perspective of the entire glacier but ended up low enough to feel the awesomeness of it. Eventually we had to climb straight up (with the help of switchbacks) the mountainside to catch the ridge trail that led back to Gornergrat. This part of the trail was challenging to both our lungs and legs, but eventually led us into fresh snow and offered views of several mountain goats. The ridge trail at the top was snow covered with amazing views in all directions. Overall, this was a highlight hike from our time in Switzerland.

title: Rim Trail
text: The Rim Trail is a flat, mostly paved trail that runs for approximately 13 miles along the South Rim of the Grand Canyon in Grand Canyon National Park. The trail is an easy walk and provide a great and beautiful overview of the canyon. We actually walked from Mather Point to Bright Angel Trailhead on the first afternoon we arrived at the canyon and then walked from South Kaibab Trailhead to Mather Point after hiking the South Kaibab trail the next day. The track below puts these two walks together as if they were one walk.

title: Hermit Trail to Santa Maria Spring
text:
Kim and I hiked the Hermit Trail of the Grand Canyon in Grand Canyon National Park from the rim to Santa Maria Spring on Feb 15 2024. The first third of the hike was snowy (but not too icy), but the remainder was mostly dry. The trail is more remote than the South Kaibab Trail that we did the previous day. The entire trail is beautiful but the last third after the junction with the Dripping Springs trail is especially gorgeous as it winds through a red canyon to the hut at Santa Maria Spring.
We were also treated along the way to a Bighorn Sheep. We initially spotted a single antler on a “shelf” about 50 feet above us. After several pictures of the antler, the sheep stood up and gave us a long and majestic side view. For some reason, the animal then quickly descended from the shelf to stop in the trail about 20’ ahead of us!! It stood there for a few minutes (as we slowly backed up) before moving across the trail to graze at the edge of a very high and sheer cliff. It was an amazing once-in-a-lifetime experience.
This was a very fun hike!

title: Boone Fork Trail
text: A couple of days after the wedding Emma lead my sister Pam, Kim, and I on the beautiful Boone Fork Trail near Blowing Rock, NC. The trail was moderately challenging with a bit of elevation change (including a ladder), several crossings of Bee Tree Creek (including some rope lines), and a nice stretch along the Boone Fork river. The trail was primarily wooded (so lots of welcome shade) with several waterfall views. I think that this is the first time I have hiked with my sister since we were kids and the second time with Emma (last time was in Wisconsin). Overall it was a great hike and a fun time!

title: Enger Park Tower & Observation Hill
text: Kim, Cash and I hiked from the Enger Park entrance, past the Enger Park Tower and Japanese Peace Bell and Garden out to Observation Hill on January 28, 2025. The trail was either part of the Superior Hiking Trail or the Duluth Traverse Trail and offered some beautiful views of Lake Superior, the aerial lift bridge, and areas inland. The tower and Japanese Peace Bell and garden were also interesting. We will come ack in the summer so that we can climb the tower.

title: Moquah Barrens Loop 1
text: On 2-Jan-2024 Cash and I walked a long (for us) loop of forest “roads” in the Moquah Barrens. Our walk began with a short stint along FR423 before turning onto FR448. FR448 looks to be an old railroad grade that is typical barrens habitat for the first (western) half or so before entering an area with some nice large pines before ending (to the East) in a large area that had been recently logged. FR449 is largely in typical barrens terrain but passes a small pond and an excellent high scenic overview. FR818 is more typical barrens terrain. Overall this was a beautiful hike with pretty easy walking (it could be driven with a good 4WD truck). Details are below.

title: Gilbertson Conservation Education Center Loop 1
text: Cash and I explored some of the trails at the Gilbertson Conservation Education Center near Elgin on 20-Mar-24. We created a large loop that took in many of the individual trails at the center. It was a nice mix of typical northeast Iowa hardwoods, some prairie land, and a stretch along the Volga River. All-in-all it was a very nice hike.

title: Echo Valley State Park
text: Cash and I walked the Echo Valley Environmental Nature Trail near Echo Valley State Park just outside of West Union once in Summer (3-Jul) 2022 and again in Winter (25-Jan) 2023. The trail starts in Echo Valley State Park and follow Otter Creek for approximately 1.5 miles. It is an easy flat trail on an old railroad (or road). The scenery was beautiful, especially in the winter. Details are below.

title: Dunning Springs Trail & Connector
text: Cash and I explored Dunning Springs Park in Decorah on 27-Jan-23. The trail to the springs is easy (and paved). The springs emanate from a limestone bluff and immediately cascade over a beautiful falls. You can walk right up to the falls or see them from above, along with the opening in the bluff, via wooded steps and an observation platform. There is also a steeply-ascending trail, the Dunning Springs Connector, that connects this area to the broader set of trails behind the Decorah Ice Cave.

title: Backbone State Park
text: Kim, Cash, and I walked “The Backbone” in Backbone State Park on 14-Jan-23. This is a short trail with the first half traversing a narrow set of limestone outcrops that form the “backbone.” This section is quite beautiful with steep dropoffs on both sides to forks of the Maquoketa River. The second half of the trail is a broad loop through a largely hardwood forest that offers further views of the river. This is a “must-see” trail if you are in the park!

title: Brush Creek Canyon State Preserve
text: Cash and I walked the road into and the trail that starts at the parking area of Brush Creek Canyon State Preserve. The trail eventually disappears but I made a loop below the bluffs to where two streams come together before eventually ending on top of the bluffs for a hike back to the parking area. This was a very beautiful hike through a mature hardwood forest with a main stream and several feeder streams as well as a number of impressive limestone bluffs. The view from the “overlook” was very nice.

title: Dutton’s Cave County Park
text: Cash and I visited Dutton’s Cave County Park near West Union on November 28, 2024. The park has two areas, an upper part that has a small primitive campground and a lower part that is primarily a picnic area with a playground. From the parking area on the lower part we walked a well-defined trail to the base of the cave. The cave is closed to humans to protect the bats from white-nose syndrome. From there we back-tracked to the picnic area and then walked up a ravine on what looked to be a maintained trail. However, the trail soon disappeared so we followed deer trails across the ravine and along the base of a number of limestone outcrops before emerging on the road that returned to the picnic area parking lot. [Here is some history about Dutton.]

title: Fish Farm Mounds State Preserve
text: Cash and I explored Fish Farm Mounds State Preserve and adjoining Fish Farm Mounds Wildlife Management Area on November 26, 2024. It is always humbling and inspiring to be near the burial sites of Indigenous peoples, thought the story (here and here) of how the mounds have been “researched” (i.e., pillaged) is, while predictable, still disheartening. The trails behind the mound complex area were well maintained (i.e., cleared) and interesting as they traversed through mature hardwoods, rocky outcrops, and deep ravines.

title: Echo Valley State Park
text: Kim, Cash and I walked the trail along Glovers Creek in the Echo Valley State Park on 17-Sep-23. We accessed the trail from the Echo Valley Environmental Nature Trail and walked upstream to the Glovers Creek access parking lot. This was a nice walk along a trail that appears to be maintained for the trout stocking truck. This was a fun hike for me as I used to fish this section of stream as a kid, before the stocking truck trail was constructed. This section held many trout that had moved downstream from the stocking that (used to) stop further upstream. In fact, I caught my second largest Iowa trout in this section! I did not take any pictures – I will have to return!

title: Barnes Barrens Loop 1
text: On 1-Feb-2024 Cash and I walked a loop of forest “trails” in the Barnes Barrens. Our walk began at Halfway Rd to head north on a counter-clockwise loop that crossed Moore Rd, Halfway Rd again, Moore Rd again, before ending back at Halfway Rd. Generally the “inside” of the loop appears to be being managed for a barrens habitat (logged, slash removed, and burnt) whereas the “outside” of the loop varied in habit from a typical barrens look to a mix of scrubby oak and pine to some rather larger (planted) pines. This was not an overly beautiful hike but I like the open view of the barrens landscape. We did not see Sharptail Grouse this day, but we have seen them when driving the section of Halfway Rd that bisects this hike. This hike was pretty easy walking (it could be driven with a 4WD truck). Details are below.

text: Kim, Cash, and I frequently make a short hike on an offroad trail to the North end of Camp Two Lake, with a loop back along an ATV trail and Ruth Lake Rd. This is a nice hike in a primarily mature hardwoods that passes small but pretty Minor Lake and ends at a makeshift camp site on the remote and beautiful Camp Two Lake (an old rowboat is permanently stashed). title: Moquah Barrens Loop 2
text: We have not made this hike yet, but it would be a good hike to see the typical but awesome barrens landscape of the Moquah Barrens. The southern border of this loop is on a fairly well-travelled forest road, whereas the other borders are on much less-traveled more off-road type forest roads. There is a power and pipe line corridor that traverses the southern third of the area, but it is not overly distracting. You can start in any of the four corners of the loop, but the NE corner is least easy to reach by truck. I started this hike in the SE corner as there is an easy parking area just across from where FR406 meets FR242. Further details are below.

title: Ely’s Peak via Short Line Trail
text: Kim, Cash and I climbed to Ely’s Peak in Duluth, MN on November 28, 2023 by starting on the Short Line trail from Becks Road. The route we took to the peak was challenging but coming down was easy as we hopped on the Superior Hiking Trail on the backside (from the direction we came). After coming down we wandered down the DWP (Duluth, Winnipeg, Pacific) trail for a ways. A highlight of the DWP was the tunnel under Ely’s Peak. Beautiful views from the top.

title: High and Middle Falls
text: We often celebrate our anniversary on the North Shore, based out of Grand Marais. We nearly always drive up to Grand Portage State Park and hike out to see the High Falls. Depending on the depth of snow we hike out to the “peak” on the Middle Falls trail and, if there is not too much snow, we will complete the hike out to Middle Falls. The views of the falls and Lake Superior are spectacular, and the trail has a little relief to it. We also enjoy the cultural display honoring the Grand Portage Ojibwe in the visitor center.

text:

title: Munger & Carlton Trails
text: On April 14, 2024, Kim, Cash, and I made a quick hike on the Willard Munger State Trail near Jay Cooke State Park. The Munger Trail is a straight, flat, paved trail with a near bridge over the St. Louis River. Soon after the bridge, we left the Munger Trail on the Carlton Trail which generally follows along the St. Louis River. We did not have much time so we did a quick spur to the banks of the river and then followed the same trail back to the parking area. The trail along the river was very beautiful in places.

title: Temperance River Loop
text: On January 12, 2024, Kim, Cash and I hiked along the Temperance River (in the Temperance River State Park) from the parking area on Highway 61. The beginning portion of the trail along the river is gorgeous with several falls and swirling plunge pools. Parts of the trail are right on the edge of the river. Upstream from all of the falls is still beautiful, just not as awe inspiring. Eventually we turned away from the river and generally walked south once the [Superior Hiking Trail]((https://superiorhiking.org/) turned north towards Carlton Peak. This portion of the trail was a very nice walk through the woods, though we were laboring some in the snow (we could have used our snow shoes). Eventually we returned to the SHT along the river where we turned back towards the parking lot. We had a very nice hike!

title: Waabizheshikana Trail Loop
text: Kim, Cash and I went to Duluth on April 2, 2024 to get “away” for a good meal and beer. As part of the day we walked the Waabizheshikana Trail in Duluth, MN, with a loop back along a few city roads. It was an interesting trail mostly through residential areas, with a few industrial areas, along the river. The weather was a little rainy and snowy, so we did not take any pictures, but we still had a good time.

title: Bridal Wreath Falls to Garwood Trail Loop
text: On February 12, 2025 Kim and I hiked the Douglas Springs Trail out to Bridal Wreath Falls. There was no water at the falls, so it was not as impressive as we had hoped (but it was not a surprise that it was dry). On the way back we took Three Tank Trail to Carillo Trail and Garwood Trail. This was a much more interesting hike with LOTS of Saguaro cacti, including the famous cristate Saguaro on the Garwood Trail.

text: On our second day in Chur (October 7, 2024) we made a couple of walks around town to get a better feel for this old city. This earlier city walk was largely around the main city. This second walk started at our hotel, wound through town to the outskirts for a steep ascent through the woods before we were stopped by trail construction. We then back tracked back to town and wound around various parts of the city before getting back to our hotel.

title: South Kaibab Trail
text: Kim and I hiked the South Kaibab Trail of the Grand Canyon in Grand Canyon National Park from the rim to Cedar Ridge on Feb 14 2024. We wore our Yak-Trax as the first third of the hike was icy and the last two-thirds was muddy (with some ice). This is a beautiful winding trail that was our introduction into descending somewhat into the canyon. The trail was moderately busy with other people but we did not feel “crowded.” The views were awesome!!

title: Gorner Gorge Loop
text: The rain let up after our Zmutt Loop hike so we decided to make the most of the day and hike through Gorner Gorge. After a short hike out of town, we paid a small fee (5.50 CHF) to enter the privately owned and maintained walkway through Gorner Gorge. The well-maintained wooden walkway is built into the side of the gorge. The hike through the gorge is short, but wonderful with several dramatic overhangs and sitelines that provide for great photos and movies. The views and feeling were well worth the admission price. After leaving the Gorge we had a short hike through the countryside and part of Zermatt proper to get back to our hotel. This was a nice cap to the day as we prepared for the Gornergrat hike the next day.

title: City and Lake Walk
text: Our last few days in Switzerland were in Lucerne. We had a great hotel right on the river and spent the two days exploring the city and lake shore. On October 12, wfter a short walk through the city to get breakfast, we did a “city walk” that led to the “Lion of Lucerne”, the Church of St. Leodegar, down to the lake to go past Lido Lucerne before turning to walk along the lake back to our hotel. This was a fun and leisurely hike.

title: Mt Falcon Ruins and Tower
text: On September 7, we managed to get in a hike at Mt Falcon Park. We followed the wide graveled Castle Trail out to the Walker House ruins and then circled back along the more rustic Meadow, Old Ute, and Tower trails that wrapped around a 7700’ peak and swung by the tower at Mt Falcon (at 7841’) and the Eagle Eye shelter. It was an amazing day to stretch our legs between concerts in this beautiful area.

title: Panaramoweg Kleine-Scheidegg to Mannlichen
text: Kim and I took the train from Lauterbrunnen to Kleine Scheidegg to walk the Panaramoweg trail to Mannlichen, including the Royal Walk, and back. This is one of the highest regarded trails in Switzerland because the trail is releatively flat and easy to walk while affording amazing views of several mountain peaks. Unfortunately, we did not have any clear days in Lauterbrunnen so we did not get to see the peaks. However, it was still a fun hike through the fog and snow. I guess we will have to return some day for the full experience.

title: Piedra Marcadas Trail
text: On February 20, 2023 Kim and I also walked the Piedra Marcadas (North Rim and main) trail in Petroglyph National Monument just outside Albuquerque. The North Rim trail is basically a walk through a mesa, but once your drop down onto the main trail the ridge is covered with numerous petroglyphs. The trail starts behind a gas station (or was it a Wallgreens) so I did not have high hopes, but both parts of the trail were interesting, with the petroglyphs being especially neat.

title: Dinosaur Ridge to Red Rocks Trading Post
text: On September 7, I hiked most of the Dinosaur Ridge Trail before heading into Red Rocks Park to meet Kim on the Trading Post Trail. The Dinosaur Ridge trail was along a closed paved road (though some buses still drove it) that lead to many “exhibits” of dinosaur bones, tracks, etc. The exhibits were interesting, though, honestly, some of them took more imagination to see than I had. The hike over to Red Rocks had some relief until the highway, after which it was fairly flat. All-in-all a fun hike, but I will probably spend my time on other trails when we return.

title: Shortoff Mountain Trail
text: A couple of days after the wedding Dillon and Emma lead Kim and I up the Shortoff Mountain Trail in the Linville Gorge Wilderness Area. The trail started with a pretty steep ascent (~1100 ft) for about 1.75 miles, before leveling off on the edge of the gorge. The views back to Lake James and into the Linville Gorge were amazing (the pictures don’t do them justice). This was a great hike with the newlyweds. Thanks Dillon and Emma for the great time and spending the first few days of your new marriage with us! Can’t wait to do it again.

title: St. Luzikapelle and Mittenberg Loop
text: On our second full day in Switzerland (October 6, 2024) we had made our way to the historic city of Chur, the oldest city in Switzerland. While we did city walks (I, II) the next day, we were itching to get into the countryside. The trail we decided on started on the edge of town fairly near our hotel and quickly climbed via several switchbacks through beautiful woods to St. Luzikapelle, a pulchritudinous little chapel in a rock grotto. From there we continued to climb until we reached an alpine meadow near Mittenberg. This area screamed “Sound of Music”, and the overlooks to the north and west were stunning. From there was a nice descent (with lots of switchbacks) back to Chur. This hike was a great introduction to the Swiss landscape, we are glad we did it.

text: After the Trummelbach Falls hike we took the train from Lauterbrunnen to Wengen and then hiked back to Lauterbrunnen, with a little side hike to Innerwengen. We were very glad to make this hike DOWNHILL to Lauterbrunnen rather than the other way around. A fun hike that afforded amazing views of the Lauterbrunnen valley and Staubbachfalle.

title: Zmutt Loop
text: Out first full day in Zermatt (October 8, 2024) was mostly cloudy and rainy. As such we decided to save the Gornergrat hike for the next day in hopes that the clouds would clear and we could see the Matterhorn. On this day then we began a hike in Zermatt that passed through Zmutt, Zmutt See, and Blatten before looping back to Zermatt. The hike up to Zmutt was classic Switzerland through woods, alpine meadows, and rustic areas with local’s cabins, while all the while hearing the dinging of livestock bells and the murmur of distant waterfalls. The trail back after crossing the Zmuttback was initially less interesting as we were on a downhill ski run. Eventually we left that and returned to a more woodsy and pastoral trail leading to the neat little towns of Zum See (we wished the restaurant would have been open, but we were off season) and Blatten. The trail after Blatten curled through some woods before crossing the river to return to Zermatt. This was a great trail to see the Swiss landscape on a rainy day. Unfortunately, we did not take a lot of pictures because of the rain.

title: Black Top Mesa from First Water TH
text: On March 9, 2022 Kim and I hiked to Black Top Mesa from the First Water trailhead via Dutchman’s and Bull Pass trails. This was a long walk for us (~12.5 mi) but offered stunning views of Weaver’s Needle from the north, which we had not seen before. The climb up to the top was steep but the trail was fairly easy to navigate. We returned to the trailhead via the Black Mesa and Second Water trails. There were many more cacti on the trail back. Fun hike. Details are below.

title: Goldmine Trail
text: On February 15, 2024 Kim and I went for a quick hike in the desert on the Goldmine Trail from the Broadway Ave Trailhead to the E Cloudview Ave “Trailhead.” This trail is relatively flat, provides some beautiful views of cacti, but was somewhat irritating with the many grapefruit sized rocks in the trail that made walking difficult and the many (needless?) “switchbacks” in the trail (zoom in on my track to see them). It was nice to get out for a quick hike, but we probably won’t do this one again (it is more interesting to hike up to the Broadway Cave).

title: Hackberry Springs Loop
text: On February 17, 2024 Kim and I hiked the Hackberry Springs trail from the First Water TH. We have done this trail previously but this time we started hiking clockwise from the overflow parking lot and then turned off on some “unofficial” trails rather than going through “the Garden” and returning on the Second Water Trail. We started midday on a beautiful Saturday, so there were lots of people out. However, there were relatively few people on the “unofficial” portions of our hike. All-in-all this was a fun hike on a beautiful day (and it is always fun to see Hackberry Springs).

title: Peralta to Canyon Lake Marina
text: On February 23, 2023 Kim and I embarked on our first walk-through hike in the Superstition Mountains. Our “support team” dropped us off at the Peralta TH about 7am when it was 45oF. It was a pretty easy hike to Fremont Saddle, which we had done before. We then dropped over the saddle and continued on the Peralta Canyon Trail past Weaver’s Needle to the Boulder Canyon Trail. It was neat to be so close to the Needle during this part of the trail. The Boulder Canyon Trail proved to be a bit challenging because the stream was fairly full of water and we had to cross it 25 times. Most crossings were pretty straight-forward, but there were several where we had to search up or downstream to find rocks close enough for both of us to cross. After our final crossing we climbed pretty steeply out of the canyon to get our first view of Canyon Lake and an awesome view back to the south of the terrain we had covered. A downhill hike to Canyon Lake Marina where our “support team” picked us up. We then went to Tortilla Flats for a beer and burger! My favorite part of this trail was seeing Weaver’s Needle from many different perspectives. All-in-all a fun trail that was 14.8 miles long and took us about 8.5 hours to complete.

title: Superstition Ridgeline West
text: On February 10, 2025 Kim and I hiked the western portion of the Superstition Ridgeline. We climbed to the Ridgeline trail via Hieroglyphics Trail and then turned west to Siphon Draw which we descended. We had a little trouble finding the trail at first (in retrospect, not sure how we missed it) and a few other places we had to search a little, but otherwise it was pretty easy to follow. The views were simply amazing, in all directions!! The only downside is that Siphon Draw is a tough descent when your legs are tired. This was a half of a bucket-list hike; we hope to do the East end (and visit Superstition Peak) next year.

title: Bayfield Rd Trail
text:
On February 7, 2024 Cash and I walked the Bayfield Road Hiking Trail (official map) in the Brule River State Forest. The trails are combined for the first XX miles before the trails split with the Copper Range spur splits to the right. The Copper Range trail is partially on old road, railroad, or logging trail grades at times and “deer trails” in the woods at other times. The entire trail is well-marked (almost too much) with blue paint, blue markers, and some signs. The markings are easy to see but if you get in a groove walking one of the grades you may miss the turn back into the woods. The trail ultimately ends either at the Brule River or at a parking area at the end of Park Rd. There is a bridge on Park Rd so that you can access the campground on the opposite side of the river.
After hiking back on the Copper Range Spur, we turned right to follow the Bayfield Hiking trail. Very quickly we came to a short spur to look down into the mine shaft, which is cordoned off with a fence for safety. Further along the trail is another short spur to an overlook with amazing views north towards Lake Superior. The trail back to the parking area passes by an old fire tower (which could be driven to as well).
All-in-all a nice scenic trail through typical northern Wisconsin woods, but with some cultural attractions.
Note that I lost satellites during this hike, so there are portions of the trail that were not mapped properly.

title: Newport State Park
text: The “big” hike on our first full day in Door County was at Newport State Park. We decided to hike out to Europe Bay Woods State Natural Area via the Europe Bay and Lynd Point trails. We got some great scenery with Lake Michigan proper to our right for the first “half” of the hike and some inland wetlands for a portion of the second “half” of the hike. This was a fun hike.

title: Whitefish Dunes State Park
text: On April 16, 2023, Kim, Cash and I hiked within Whitefish Dunes State Park. We actually started in Cave Point County Park before heading south to catch the Brachiopod Trail in the state park. We followed that to the Nature Center Office to catch the start of the Red Trail. We hopped off the Red Trail several times to “spur” over to the beach and Whitefish Bay, before hopping on the boardwalk to see the “Old Baldy” dune. From there we looped inland on the Yellow and Green trails to the Nature Center before retracing our steps to the county park. A really nice and scenic trail.

I also tend to our Oulu property, fish, boat, cross-country ski, snowshoe, attend live music, and smoke fish and meat. I also make occasional TV appearances, the most famous of these is my appearance on Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline II
text:
In a previous post I introduced the Pike Chain of Lakes, explained temperature profile plots and the typical seasonality of temperature by depth data, and examined temperature by depth data that are publicly available through the Wisconsin DNR Citizen Lake Monitoring Network. Here I explore dissolved oxygen data from the same source.
 






Summary




Multiple dissolved oxygen profiles can be constructed for each year since 2012.
Dissolved oxygen profiles closely match the temperature profiles relative to the thermocline.
Dissolved oxygen values above the thermocline were nearly always above 6 mg/L, which is considered to be good oxygen levels for warmwater fishes.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline II
text:
In a previous post I introduced the Pike Chain of Lakes, explained temperature profile plots and the typical seasonality of temperature by depth data, and examined temperature by depth data that are publicly available through the Wisconsin DNR Citizen Lake Monitoring Network. Here I explore dissolved oxygen data from the same source.
 






Summary




Multiple dissolved oxygen profiles can be constructed for each year since 2012.
Dissolved oxygen profiles closely match the temperature profiles relative to the thermocline.
Dissolved oxygen values above the thermocline were nearly always above 6 mg/L, which is considered to be good oxygen levels for warmwater fishes.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline II
text:
Temperature Oxygen Relationship & Seasonality
As noted in the previous post, deep lakes in our area develop a thermocline in the summer, with relatively warm water near the surface (to approximately 25-30 feet) and relatively cool water near the bottom of the lake, with a zone of rapidly decreasing temperature (the thermocline) in between. The colder deeper water is more dense then the warmer surface waters and the thermocline in between limits the ability of the water in these two zones to mix. Generally, all plant life and plant growth occurs in the warmer surface waters, thus, producing oxygen (in dissolved format) for this zone. In contrast, in the deeper zone, no new oxygen is being added and oxygen is being used by bacteria as organic matter is broken down. These processes result in a fairly well oxygenated zone above the thermocline and an area of (sometimes extreme) oxygen depletion below the thermocline. The result is that the dissolved oxygen profile tends to be very similar to the temperature profile (Figure 1).








Figure 1: Temperature and dissolved oxygen profile plots for August 1, 1991. The thin line at the top represents the water surface and the thicker line at the bottom represents the lake bottom.





 
The oxygen profile just described sets up quickly on our lakes following the spring turnover period. Our Eagle Lake data does not include samples from early enough in the year to show the vertical mixing throughout the water column. However, Figure 2 shows the general pattern described above for all sample dates, but also shows the general tend that dissolved oxygen in the upper layer is higher in the early and late samples as cooler water can hold more dissolved oxygen.








Figure 2: Dissolved oxygen profile plots for nine dates throughout the open-water season in 2020.





You may also notice a peak in DO just above the thermocline on many dates. This is the result of hypersaturation of oxygen at that depth due to the temperature cooling faster than the oxygen can be depleted. Thus, for a period of time when the top of thermocline is getting deeper, the oxygen from the once cooler water will be higher than the now warmer water would likely contain (thus, being over- or hyper-saturated).

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline II
text:
Eagle Lake DO Profiles








Figure 3: Dissolved oxygen profiles separated by year (panels) and observation dates. Profile colors start with blue for early May transition through purple and pink to red for early July and then transition through orange and brown to green for late fall. The vertical dashed red line is at 6 mg/L.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline II
text:
Resources

Dissolved Oxygen and Temperature at Michigan State U.
Vertical Mixing and Turnover at Britannica.com
Thermocline at BoatSafe.com
Water Quality Criteria from the EPA (see Table 1 on page 216 for DO concentrations)

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline
text:
The Pike Chain of Lakes near Iron River, WI is a set of nine connected lakes, seven of which have relatively consistent water quality data. The Pike Chain is highly developed, has several public access locations, and is popular among anglers, boaters, snowmobilers, etc. year-round. Over the years, especially recently since Eurasian watermilfoil was introduced, volunteers have recorded various water quality parameters for the Pike Chain of Lakes. Below I show the record of temperature by depth recordings for one of the lakes (Eagle) that are publicly available through the Wisconsin DNR Citizen Lake Monitoring Network.
 






Summary




Multiple temperature profiles can be constructed for each year since 2012.
The thermocline has begun to form by the earliest observations in May and is beginning to breakup in October (where those observations exist).
The top of the thermocline is generally between 15-20 feet deep in mid to late summer.
The bottom of the thermocline is generally between 25-30 feet deep in mid to late summer.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline
text:
The Pike Chain of Lakes near Iron River, WI is a set of nine connected lakes, seven of which have relatively consistent water quality data. The Pike Chain is highly developed, has several public access locations, and is popular among anglers, boaters, snowmobilers, etc. year-round. Over the years, especially recently since Eurasian watermilfoil was introduced, volunteers have recorded various water quality parameters for the Pike Chain of Lakes. Below I show the record of temperature by depth recordings for one of the lakes (Eagle) that are publicly available through the Wisconsin DNR Citizen Lake Monitoring Network.
 






Summary




Multiple temperature profiles can be constructed for each year since 2012.
The thermocline has begun to form by the earliest observations in May and is beginning to breakup in October (where those observations exist).
The top of the thermocline is generally between 15-20 feet deep in mid to late summer.
The bottom of the thermocline is generally between 25-30 feet deep in mid to late summer.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline
text:
Temperature Profile Plot
A temperature profile plot shows the water temperature at various depths through the water column (Figure 1). Depth is shown with the water surface at the top and the lake bottom at the bottom of the left axis. Temperature increases from left to right on the bottom axis.








Figure 1: Temperature profile plot for August 1, 1991. The thin line at the top represents the water surface and the thicker line at the bottom represents the lake bottom.





Figure 1 illustrates a typical mid-summer profile where the temperature is fairly and consistently warm near the surface (75-80oF from 0 to 15 ft) declines quickly over a fairly narrow depth range (drops from 75oF to 50oF from 15 to 30 ft) and then stays fairly and consistently cool at greater depths.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline
text:
Seasonal Changes in Temperature Profile
In winter (under the ice in northern Wisconsin) and at ice-out the water temperature will be a nearly constant 39oF from top to bottom (perhaps a little cooler at the ice-water interface). However, as spring progresses the surface water becomes warmer and, moving into summer, that warmer water will extend deeper into the lake. However, in most lakes in our area there will be a depth where the water temperature begins to decline dramatically over a fairly narrow depth range (see Figure 1). Eventually there will be a depth where the water temperatures stays fairly and constantly cold below that depth. The transition zone of water temperatures quickly declining from warmer surface to cooler below-surface water is called the thermocline. As fall approaches the process is reversed such that the surface water will cool (and, thus, sink) until the water temperature is again fairly constant throughout the water column.
On Eagle Lake we do not have water column temperature data very near the ice-out and ice-in dates. Thus, the seasonal phenomenon just described cannot be fully illustrated for Eagle Lake. However, Figure 2 shows the general trend of warmer surface water, the thermocline, and cooler water at deeper depths through the open-water months. The warming and then cooling of the surface water layer is also evident in Figure 2. Finally, the dissolution of the thermocline in late fall was evident on the last observation date of October 16 (Figure 2).








Figure 2: Temperature profile plots for nine dates throughout the open-water season in 2020.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline
text:
Eagle Lake Temperature Profiles








Figure 3: Temperature profiles separated by year (panels) and observation dates. Profile colors start with blue for early May and then transitions through purple and pink to red for early July and then through orange and brown to green for late October.

title: Eagle Lake Thermocline

title: Pike Chain of Lakes Secchi Depths
text:
The Pike Chain of Lakes near Iron River, WI is a set of nine connected lakes (Figure 1). The Pike Chain is highly developed, has several public access locations, and is popular among anglers, boaters, snowmobilers, etc. year-round. Over the years, especially recently since Eurasian watermilfoil was introduced, volunteers have recorded various water quality parameters for the Pike Chain of lakes. Below I show the record of Secchi depth recordings that are publicly available through the Wisconsin DNR Citizen Lake Monitoring Network.








Figure 1: Satellite image of the nine lakes that form the Pike Chain of Lakes.





A Secchi disk is an 8-inch disk painted in quadrants with black and white that is lowered into a lake to assess water clarity. The depth at which the disk is no longer visible is called the Secchi depth and is a measure of water transparency; the deeper the depth the more transparent the water. Water transparency can be a surrogate for water quality (more transparent generally means higher water quality) and can be an indicator of human activity on and around the lake. See this and this for quick introductions to Secchi disks.
 






Summary




Data was inconsistently recorded across lakes.
Muskellunge Lake had the shallowest Secchi depth, whereas Lake Millicent and Hart Lake had the deepest (see Figure 2).
Average Secchi depth varied annually within each lake, with no clear trend of increasing or decreasing in most lakes (see Figure 3),

title: Little Manitou Falls via Beaver Trail
text: On May 1, 2023 Kim, Cash and I explored around Pattison State Park. We initially walked over to Big Manitou Falls, but I did not map that part for some reason. We then followed the Beaver Trail on the west side of Interfalls Lake out to the Little Manitou Falls trail to Little Manitou Falls. We got some great pictures of Cash there before backtracking, crossing the CCC Bridge, and following the Beaver Trail on the east side of Interfalls Lake back to the parking area. All-in-all a fun day.

title: Houghton Falls Area
text: We often hike the trails at the Houghton Falls Nature Preserve just outside of Washburn, WI. The main trail heads from an access parking lot through a beautiful area to a nice sandstone “cliff” on Lake Superior (i.e,. Houghton Point). However, there are a few side trails that go down into the sandstone “dells” that are fun, especially if there is some water in the creek. The trails shown below are from a full day of exploring with Cash and include a side trail on the “other side” of the creek and an old road this is likely a snowmobile trail in the winter. Houghton Falls/Point is always a fun, quick hike.

title: Makwa Ziibiins Miikana Trail
text: On April 26, 2022 Cash and I hiked the Makwa Ziibiins Miikana Trail in Superior, WI. This is a fun little trail from the edge of town out to wetlands on Allouez Bay. When we were there they were just starting to build a floating boardwalk through the wetlands to connect with Wisconsin Point. My understanding is that it is now complete. We will have to do this trail again.

title: Apple Blossom Overlook Park
text: On the way to Iowa on October 25, 2024, we stopped to stretch our legs and get Cash some exercise on the trail in Apple Blossom Overlook Park just outside of La Crescent, MN. This was a nice little trail in a mix of open “prairie” uplands and mixed hardwood forest. The overlook looked down on the town of La Crescent and over the Mississippi River to La Crosse.

title: Paper Mill Trail and Whiting Park Loop
text: Cash and I were in Stevens Point to pick up a part for the boat. For a break we hiked the Paper Mill Trail of the Green Circle Trail and looped around Whiting Park. The Paper Mill Trail was fairly flat and well-maintained. It provide nice views of the river and was quite nice, besides a short section that felt very (old) industrial. The loop in the park was very nice and a little more “rugged” (less-maintained), with the only down-side needing to walk along Water St to make the loop. All-in-all this was a nice hike for a break.

title: Pikes Peak State Park Loop 1
text: On our trips to Iowas we will often stop at Pikes Peak State Park to let Cash stretch his legs. One of my favorite loops is to start at the overlook of the Mississippi River and take Bridal Veil Falls Trail (I still haven’t seen the falls with water yet) to East Hickory Ridge Trail which we take out to another overlook of the river. We then follow the West Hickory Ridge Trail to the Weeping Rock Trail back to the parking lot. It is interesting that on the Bridal Falls and Hickory Ridge trails your can see (from a rspectful dstance) effigy mounds created by indigenous peoples.

title: Pinicon Ridge County Park
text: My sister Pam met Cash and I for a nice walk through Pinicon Ridge County Park. We started at the “Elk pen” parking area on the west side of the Wapsipinicon River, walked through the park on the west side to join the Wapsi River Nature Trail. We followed this across the river via the the Mary Lundby Bridge through the campgrounds on the east side before connecting with the Central City Trail at Highway 13. We followed this into town to connect with streets and roads to loop back to the original parking lot. We used to camp here often when we were kids, so it was fun to re-visit the area.

text: Cash and I walked from the Osborne Nature Center parking area along the Volga River, returning mostly along a ridge above the river. The trail was short, but nice. title: Osborne County Park
text: After walking the short trails along the Volga River in the south side of Osborne Park, Cash and I decided to walk the trails on the north side that wound through a disc golf course, archery range, an old quary, and an old cemetary. This was a nice mix of prairie, hardwoods, river bottoms, and area around a constructed pond. Overall, a nice hike with still more trails to explore. It was a very warm March day (83F)!

title: Split Rock Shore to Day Hill
text: On January 4, 2026, Kim, Cash, and I hiked in Split Rock Lighthouse State Park from the parking area on Highway 61, across 61 along the Lake Superior shoreline up to the Day Hill Lookout. This was a fun trail through a variety of habitats, including areas where the trail was close to Lake Superior. There is a neat set of stairs on the lake side of Day Hill and the view from Day Hill was beautiful, including a glimpse north to the Split Rock Lighthouse.

title: Pincushion Mountain Overlook
text: On January 3, 2026, Kim, Cash, and I hiked the portion of the Superior Hiking Trail from the Pincushion Mountain trailhead to the Pincushion Mountain Overlook. This was a fairly flat trail through a variety of habitats, including several winding boardwalks through cedar groves, until the spur up to the overlook. The views from the overlook were amazing. We looking forward to walking the trail further to the Devil Track River gorge in the future.

title: Lookout Mountain Overlook
text: On January 3, 2026, Kim, Cash, and I hiked the portion of the Superior Hiking Trail in Cascade River State Park from the parking area on Highway 61 out to Lookout Mountain. The trail is along the Cascade River gorge at first, with many beautiful waterfalls and plunge pools. It then turns away from the river and meanders through the woods until climbing to Lookout Mountain. A nice hike!

title: Hatchery Creek Trail I
text: Cash and I made a quick loop in the Hatchery Creek system of trails just outside of Hayward when we were traveling south in Fall 2025. The rolling and upland woods trail was quite pretty with a decent amount of relief. I think much of the trail was a bike trail so some of the switchbacks were getting kind of old. However, all-in-all a nice hike.

title: Meyers Beach Lake Shore Trail
text: One of our favorite hikes is the Lake Shore Trail at Meyers Beach in the Apostle Islands National Lakeshore. While often quite busy with other hikers it is still a nice hike above the sea caves along the Lake Superior shore. The views of The Crevasse, pillars, and The Bowl are always great.

title: Effigy Mounds National Monument
text: Kim, Cash, and I explored the “Main Mounds Trail” at Effigy Mounds National Monument on 27-Oct-25. This is an area that I have known about since I was a kid, but have never visited. The government was on shutdown so the Visitor Center was not open but the flags from the indigenous nations represented in this area were displayed outside and set a tone of respect for the culture we were about to experience. The trail begins with a steep climb to a “plateau” with several beautiful overlooks of the Mississippi River as well as impressive animal shaped burial mounds. We did not quite hit peak fall colors but it was still a beautiful hike through the hardwoods. We hope to come back when the Visitor Center is open, the colors are at peak, and we have enough time to explore the other trails. Note that, out of respect, I do not show any pictures of the mounds

title: Ice Cave City Loop
text: A number of times while passing through Decorah we will take some sort of hike on the numerous nice trails in the city. Several times we start near Phelps Park on the Oneonta Trail and create a loop on the Ice Cave Rd by Ice Cave State Preserve and Dunning Springs Park circling back through town to our car. This is a pretty hike that is mostly along the river, though some woods, with fun sights at the cave and springs.
